rounds.response:
I have 7♠ 5♠ in the big-blind (out of position against the small-blind only).  
That’s suited one-gapper, roughly the bottom 25 % of starting hands heads-up.  
The pot is 30 and I only need to call an additional 10 chips; with implied odds of 3-to-1 it is +EV to see a flop, especially in position post-flop (after the small-blind must act first).

[Call]

rounds.response:
I'm now the big blind (P1) facing the river with a top-pair/top-kicker. There's 440 in the pot effective on me and I have 800 behind. Over two streets, P0 has taken every chance to bet for size—60 on the flop and 140 on the turn—which narrows their range to value (boat with Q4, trips with Qx, or possibly an overplayed JJ) and bluffs with missed broadway/combo draws. My hand (AQ) loses to made boats/trips but beats all bluffs. A “check-call” here is the line that keeps all of P0’s bluffs alive and forces value to bet for me. If they check back, we still showdown the best one-pair hand a high percentage of the time.

[Check]

[K♥ 9♣] gives me an open-ended straight draw (any 10 for the nut straight, any Q for the top end). There’s also a potential back-door flush possibility if running clubs come, but the queen and ace on board already threaten higher flushes. With the board texture (broadway-heavy and connected):

- I beat nothing except pure bluffs right now.  
- P1 has only checked behind; he likely has at least an ace or jack (top pair) but not necessarily stronger.  
- My effective stack is 300 and the pot is 40, so bet-fold lines aren’t attractive when pot-committed.  

My best EV play is to take the free card and realize my equity; I’ll check.

[Check]
